title: Gas Safety
legalBasis: Royal Decree 919/2006 on regulation of gas installations; ITC-ICG technical instructions; Law 31/1995 on Occupational Risk Prevention; Royal Decree 1027/2007 (RITE) on thermal installations; UNE 60670 standards for gas installations in buildings
summary:
Gas installations in hospitality establishments present significant safety risks, including fire, explosion, asphyxiation, and carbon monoxide poisoning. Natural gas (methane) and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG, including butane and propane) are widely used in commercial kitchens for cooking, water heating, and space heating due to their efficiency, precise temperature control, and lower operating costs compared to electric alternatives. However, these fuels are inherently hazardous: gas leaks can create explosive atmospheres, incomplete combustion produces toxic carbon monoxide, and equipment malfunctions can result in fires or explosions.

Royal Decree 919/2006 establishes comprehensive regulations for gas installations in Spain, covering design, installation, inspection, maintenance, and modification of gas systems. All gas installations must be designed and installed by authorized gas installation companies (empresas instaladoras de gas autorizadas), and periodic inspections by authorized technicians are legally required to maintain operating certificates. The ITC-ICG series of technical instructions provides detailed specifications for gas installations, covering piping materials and sizing, ventilation requirements, safety devices, and installation procedures for different types of premises and equipment.

Effective gas safety requires a multi-layered approach combining properly designed and maintained installations, functional safety devices, adequate ventilation, regular inspection and maintenance, comprehensive staff training in normal operation and emergency procedures, and a culture of vigilance where any signs of gas-related problems are immediately reported and addressed. Failure to maintain gas safety standards can result in catastrophic incidents with multiple fatalities, criminal liability for responsible persons, and business closure.
keyPoints: All gas installations must be designed, installed, and modified only by authorized gas installation companies
Annual inspections by authorized gas installers are mandatory to maintain operating certificates and insurance coverage
Staff must be trained to recognize gas leak indicators: smell, sound, visible disturbance, and dead vegetation near lines
Emergency gas shut-off procedures must be known by all staff, with main shut-off valve locations clearly marked and accessible
Adequate ventilation is critical to prevent carbon monoxide accumulation and to dilute any leaked gas below explosive concentrations
Gas equipment must have functioning flame failure safety devices that automatically shut off gas supply if flames extinguish
Never use open flames, electrical switches, or any spark-producing actions if gas leak is suspected; evacuate and call emergency services
Carbon monoxide detectors should be installed in areas with gas combustion equipment and tested regularly
Gas cylinders (butane/propane) must be stored upright, secured, in well-ventilated areas away from heat sources
Immediate evacuation and emergency services notification (112) are required if gas leak cannot be quickly isolated and controlled

sections.heading: 1. Gas Types and Properties in Hospitality
sections.content:
Understanding the properties of the gases used in your establishment is fundamental to recognizing hazards and responding appropriately to incidents. Natural gas (primarily methane) is supplied through underground piping networks from regional distribution systems. It is lighter than air, so leaked natural gas tends to rise and accumulate at high points in rooms or dissipate upward in open areas. Natural gas is naturally odorless; a distinctive odorant (typically mercaptan) is added so that concentrations as low as 1% can be detected by smell before they reach explosive levels (5-15% concentration in air).

Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG), including butane and propane, is stored under pressure as a liquid in cylinders or bulk tanks and vaporizes when released to atmospheric pressure. LPG is significantly heavier than air; leaked LPG sinks and accumulates at floor level, in basements, drains, and low-lying areas where it can create persistent explosive pockets that are difficult to ventilate. This property makes LPG leaks particularly dangerous in basement kitchens or areas without adequate low-level ventilation. LPG also has an added odorant for leak detection.

Both gases are highly flammable and form explosive mixtures with air over specific concentration ranges. Natural gas becomes explosive at 5-15% concentration in air; LPG at 2-10%. Within these ranges, any ignition source — an electrical spark, a pilot light, even a static electricity discharge — can cause an explosion. Carbon monoxide is produced by both gases when combustion occurs with insufficient oxygen supply, typically due to inadequate ventilation, blocked flues, or malfunctioning burners. Carbon monoxide is odorless, colorless, and highly toxic, binding to hemoglobin in blood more effectively than oxygen and causing rapid unconsciousness and death.

subsections.heading: 1.1 Regulatory Framework for Gas Installations
subsections.content:
Royal Decree 919/2006 is the principal regulation governing gas installations in Spain, establishing requirements for installation companies, technicians, materials, design standards, and inspection protocols. Gas installations are classified by pressure: low pressure (up to 50 mbar, typical for end-use appliances), medium pressure (50 mbar to 4 bar, used in distribution within buildings), and high pressure (above 4 bar, used in primary distribution networks). Most hospitality establishments operate low-pressure systems, but larger operations may have medium-pressure installations requiring additional safety measures.

Installation companies (empresas instaladoras) and individual technicians (instaladores autorizados) must be registered with the competent regional authority and demonstrate technical competence through certification. Only authorized companies may install, modify, or perform major repairs on gas installations. Routine maintenance and minor adjustments can be performed by authorized service technicians, but any work affecting the gas supply system or safety-critical components requires an authorized installer. Unauthorized work on gas installations is not only illegal but voids insurance coverage and creates serious liability in the event of an incident.

subsections.heading: 1.2 Installation Certificates and Inspection Requirements
subsections.content:
All new gas installations and substantial modifications must be certified by the installing company and inspected by an authorized control entity (entidad de control) before commissioning. The installation certificate (certificado de instalación) confirms that the installation complies with applicable regulations and technical standards. This certificate must be submitted to the regional industry authority and is required to contract gas supply with the distribution company.

Periodic inspections are required at intervals determined by the type of installation: typically every five years for commercial installations, though higher-risk installations may require annual inspection. Periodic inspections verify that the installation remains compliant, components are in good condition, safety devices function correctly, ventilation is adequate, and no unauthorized modifications have been made. Following inspection, a favorable report must be obtained to maintain the installation's operating certificate. Failure to conduct periodic inspections can result in gas supply disconnection, insurance policy cancellation, and regulatory sanctions.

sections.heading: 2. Gas Leak Detection and Emergency Response
sections.content:
Rapid detection of gas leaks is critical to preventing explosions and toxic exposures. The most reliable detection method is olfactory — the distinctive smell of odorant added to gas. Staff must be trained to immediately recognize this smell and distinguish it from other odors in the kitchen environment. The smell is often described as resembling rotten eggs or sulfur. Any detection of gas odor must be treated as a serious emergency requiring immediate action. The auditory detection — a hissing or whistling sound indicating escaping gas under pressure — is also a critical warning sign, particularly for larger leaks.

Visual indicators of gas leaks can include soil disturbance, dead or discolored vegetation along gas line routes (gas displaces oxygen in soil), bubbles in standing water or puddles near pipework, white mist or fog near gas lines (caused by pressure reduction and temperature drop as gas escapes), or dust or debris being blown from the ground. Inside buildings, visual indicators are less common but may include movement of lightweight materials (curtains, papers) near suspected leak points due to gas flow. Modern installations may include automated gas detection systems that trigger alarms when gas concentrations exceed safe levels; these systems are particularly important in areas with LPG where heavier-than-air gas can accumulate undetected.

Emergency response to suspected gas leaks must be immediate, systematic, and strictly followed. The fundamental principle is to eliminate ignition sources, ventilate the area, isolate the gas supply, evacuate if necessary, and summon expert assistance. Incorrect actions during gas leak emergencies — particularly creating sparks or failing to evacuate when required — have resulted in catastrophic explosions in hospitality establishments. Every staff member must know the emergency response protocol and understand that their actions in the critical first minutes can prevent disaster.

subsections.heading: 2.1 Gas Leak Emergency Protocol
subsections.content:
When gas odor is detected or a gas leak is suspected, the immediate actions are: DO NOT operate any electrical switches, lights, or equipment (turning on or off creates sparks); DO NOT use mobile phones in the affected area; DO NOT search for the leak source with open flame or spark-producing devices; DO NOT attempt to relight pilot lights or ignite burners; DO NOT use elevators. Instead, the correct procedure is: alert others verbally (don't use PA systems or alarms that might spark); open windows and doors to ventilate, creating cross-ventilation if possible; evacuate customers and non-essential staff to a safe distance (at least 50 meters from the building); shut off the main gas supply valve if location is known, accessible, and safe to reach.

For LPG systems, be aware that opening high-level windows and doors may not effectively ventilate heavier-than-air gas that has accumulated at floor level; low-level ventilation openings are more effective. From a safe distance outside the building, call the gas emergency number (natural gas suppliers have 24-hour emergency services) and emergency services (112). Provide clear information: address, nature of the suspected leak, whether gas supply has been shut off, whether anyone is injured, and the type of gas involved. Do not re-enter the building until emergency services or gas company technicians have declared it safe.

subsections.heading: 2.2 Gas Detection Equipment
subsections.content:
Portable gas detectors are available for proactive leak detection during maintenance and inspection. These electronic devices detect combustible gas concentrations in air and provide visual and audible warnings when levels approach dangerous thresholds. Detectors should be used by maintenance personnel to check installations, particularly when reconnecting equipment, after installation modifications, or when investigating suspected leaks. Detectors must be calibrated according to manufacturer specifications to ensure accurate readings.

Fixed gas detection systems provide continuous monitoring and are advisable in higher-risk installations, particularly where LPG is used and could accumulate in low-lying areas, in basement kitchens, or in areas without natural ventilation. These systems consist of strategically positioned sensors connected to a control panel that triggers alarms and can automatically shut off gas supply when dangerous concentrations are detected. Carbon monoxide detectors are separate devices that monitor for combustion products; they should be installed in any area with gas-fired appliances and particularly in areas where flue gases could spill back into occupied spaces.

subsections.heading: 2.3 Main Gas Shut-off Procedures
subsections.content:
Every hospitality establishment with gas supply must have clearly identified main gas shut-off valves, and all staff must know their locations and how to operate them. The main shut-off is typically located where the gas supply enters the building — often near the front entrance, in a ground-floor utility area, or in an external meter cabinet. The valve should be clearly labeled 'GAS — EMERGENCY SHUT-OFF' in Spanish and ideally with visual signage understandable regardless of language proficiency.

Gas shut-off valves typically require a quarter-turn (90 degrees) to close. In the OFF position, the valve handle should be perpendicular to the pipe; in the ON position, parallel to the pipe. The valve should be accessible at all times, not locked or blocked by equipment or supplies. In establishments with multiple gas supply points or areas, secondary isolation valves should be identified for each area or piece of equipment, allowing selective shut-off without disrupting gas supply to the entire facility. After shutting off gas supply in an emergency, only authorized gas technicians should restore supply after verifying that the issue has been resolved and the installation is safe.

sections.heading: 3. Gas Equipment Safety and Maintenance
sections.content:
Gas-fired equipment in commercial kitchens includes ranges, ovens, griddles, charbroilers, deep fryers, salamanders, combination ovens, water heaters, and space heaters. Each piece of equipment must be properly installed according to manufacturer specifications and regulatory requirements, with adequate ventilation, appropriate clearances from combustible materials, and functioning safety devices. Installation must ensure stable connection to the gas supply — rigid piping or approved flexible connectors — with no strain on connections and secure leak-free joints verified by pressure testing and soap-solution leak checking.

Flame failure safety devices are mandatory on all gas cooking equipment. These devices automatically shut off gas supply if the flame is extinguished, preventing unburned gas from accumulating and creating an explosion risk. The most common type is a thermocouple or flame rectification system that senses flame presence and maintains a gas valve in the open position; if the flame extinguishes, the sensor cools or loses signal, and the valve closes automatically. Staff must understand that if flame failure devices repeatedly trip or if equipment is difficult to light, this indicates a malfunction requiring immediate professional service.

Daily operational checks before lighting equipment should include visual inspection of burners for blockages (food debris, carbon deposits), verification that control knobs operate smoothly and return to the off position when released, checking that pilot lights (where present) are lit and burning steadily with a small, blue flame, and ensuring that ventilation systems are operating before starting cooking operations. Burners should ignite quickly when opened and burn with a stable blue flame; a yellow or orange flame indicates incomplete combustion (producing carbon monoxide) and requires burner adjustment by a qualified technician.

subsections.heading: 3.1 Preventive Maintenance Schedules
subsections.content:
Annual preventive maintenance by qualified gas equipment service technicians is essential for safety and equipment longevity. Comprehensive maintenance includes: cleaning burners and removing carbon deposits that can affect combustion efficiency and air-fuel mixture; adjusting primary and secondary air shutters to ensure complete combustion (blue flame without yellow tips); testing flame failure devices for proper operation; inspecting and cleaning pilot assemblies; checking control valves and thermostats for proper operation; inspecting gas connections for corrosion, deterioration, or stress; pressure-testing connections for leaks; verifying adequate ventilation and flue operation; and cleaning or replacing filters in ventilation systems.

Maintenance must be documented with service reports indicating work performed, any deficiencies identified, parts replaced, and confirmation that equipment was tested and returned to safe operating condition. Equipment found to have safety defects must be taken out of service immediately until repairs are completed. Deferred maintenance is a false economy in gas equipment; malfunctioning equipment not only poses immediate safety hazards but also operates inefficiently, wasting fuel and often producing inferior cooking results.

subsections.heading: 3.2 Burner Flame Characteristics and Adjustments
subsections.content:
Proper burner flame characteristics indicate complete combustion, which is both safe and efficient. A correctly adjusted gas flame should be predominantly blue, with minimal yellow or orange color, compact and stable without lifting off the burner or impinging on cookware, and quiet without roaring or whistling sounds. Yellow or orange flames indicate incomplete combustion — typically caused by insufficient air supply — which produces carbon monoxide, wastes fuel, and deposits soot on cookware and equipment.

Flames that lift off the burner (appear separated from burner ports) or blow out easily indicate excessive primary air or gas pressure problems. Noisy flames suggest turbulent gas flow, often caused by excessive gas pressure or partially blocked burners. Uneven flames or flames only on portions of a burner ring indicate blocked burner ports. Any of these conditions requires adjustment by a qualified technician; operators should not attempt to adjust burners themselves as incorrect adjustment can create dangerous conditions. However, operators can and should report abnormal flame conditions promptly to ensure timely service.

subsections.heading: 3.3 Ventilation and Combustion Air Requirements
subsections.content:
Adequate ventilation is essential both for removing combustion products (carbon dioxide, water vapor, and trace amounts of carbon monoxide) and for providing combustion air to ensure complete burning of gas. Commercial kitchen ventilation systems consist of exhaust hoods that capture hot combustion products and cooking effluents, ductwork that conveys exhaust outside, and makeup air systems that replace exhausted air to prevent negative pressure in the kitchen.

Insufficient combustion air causes incomplete combustion, producing dangerous levels of carbon monoxide. Signs of inadequate combustion air include yellow or orange flames, soot deposits, excessive condensation on windows or cold surfaces, pilot lights that frequently blow out, and backdrafting (combustion products spilling into the room rather than being exhausted). Natural ventilation through windows and doors may be sufficient for small equipment loads, but commercial kitchens typically require mechanical makeup air systems designed to provide the required air volume based on exhaust rates and combustion requirements.

sections.heading: 4. LPG Cylinder Management and Storage
sections.content:
Liquefied petroleum gas (butane and propane) supplied in pressurized cylinders is common in smaller hospitality establishments, outdoor catering operations, and as backup systems. LPG cylinders must be handled, stored, and connected with careful attention to safety requirements. Cylinders are pressure vessels containing liquefied gas under pressure (butane at approximately 2 bar at 15°C; propane at approximately 8 bar); mishandling can result in valve damage, leaks, fires, or cylinder rupture.

Cylinder storage must comply with specific regulatory requirements. Cylinders should be stored upright and secured to prevent falling (a fallen cylinder can have its valve sheared off, resulting in a gas jet fire or projectile hazard). Storage areas must be well-ventilated, ideally outdoors or in dedicated, ventilated compartments; never store cylinders in basements or unventilated spaces where leaked gas could accumulate. Cylinders must be protected from weather extremes, particularly excessive heat (which increases internal pressure) and direct sunlight. Storage must be away from ignition sources, electrical equipment, and combustible materials, with minimum distances specified in ITC-ICG technical instructions.

Connection and disconnection of cylinders is a critical operation requiring trained, competent personnel. Connectors must be appropriate for the gas type and pressure, and must be in good condition without cracks, perishing, or damage. The connection procedure includes: verifying the cylinder valve is closed before connection; visually inspecting the cylinder, valve, and connector for damage; ensuring the connection threads or clip-on fitting is clean and undamaged; making the connection hand-tight (for threaded connections) or ensuring secure clip engagement (for push-fit connections); checking for leaks using soapy water solution (never using open flame); and only then opening the cylinder valve slowly.

subsections.heading: 4.1 Cylinder Handling Safety
subsections.content:
LPG cylinders must be handled with care to prevent damage to the cylinder or valve. When transporting cylinders, they should be kept upright and secured to prevent movement. Cylinder valves should be closed and, where provided, protective caps should be fitted to prevent valve damage during transport. Cylinders should never be rolled, dropped, or subjected to impact. Manual handling techniques are important; cylinders are heavy (a standard 12.5 kg butane cylinder weighs approximately 25 kg when full) and awkward to carry.

Never attempt to repair, modify, or refill cylinders; this must only be done by authorized LPG suppliers using certified processes. Cylinders showing signs of damage (dents, corrosion, fire damage, valve damage) should be returned to the supplier and not used. Cylinders have finite service lives; modern cylinders have date stamps indicating inspection and expiry dates. Cylinders past their expiry dates should not be accepted or used. When cylinders are empty, valves should be closed, and cylinders should be stored separately from full cylinders to prevent confusion.

subsections.heading: 4.2 Changeover Procedures and Leak Testing
subsections.content:
Changeover from an empty cylinder to a full one is a routine operation that must be performed correctly every time. Before disconnecting an empty cylinder, ensure all gas equipment supplied by that cylinder is turned off. Close the cylinder valve and allow equipment to burn off residual gas until flames extinguish. Disconnect the regulator or hose from the empty cylinder using appropriate tools if required (some connections are hand-tight; others require wrenches). Before connecting the new cylinder, inspect the cylinder valve outlet for damage or contamination; briefly open and close the cylinder valve to clear any debris from the outlet (do this outdoors, away from ignition sources).

After making the connection to the full cylinder, perform a leak test before opening the valve fully and lighting equipment. Apply soapy water solution (or commercial leak detection solution) to all connection points. Slowly open the cylinder valve slightly and observe the connections; the presence of growing bubbles indicates a leak. If a leak is detected, close the cylinder valve, disconnect, inspect connections for damage, and reconnect. If the leak persists, do not use the cylinder; return it to the supplier. Only when leak testing confirms no leaks should the cylinder valve be opened fully and equipment operation resumed.

sections.heading: 5. Carbon Monoxide Awareness and Prevention
sections.content:
Carbon monoxide (CO) is a toxic gas produced by incomplete combustion of any carbon-containing fuel, including natural gas and LPG. It is odorless, colorless, and tasteless, making it impossible to detect without instruments. CO poisoning is a significant hazard in hospitality environments, where multiple gas appliances operate in enclosed spaces, often for extended periods. CO binds to hemoglobin in the blood approximately 200 times more readily than oxygen, preventing oxygen transport to tissues and causing cellular asphyxiation. Symptoms of CO poisoning include headache, dizziness, nausea, fatigue, confusion, and loss of consciousness; high-level exposures can be rapidly fatal.

Prevention of CO accumulation requires ensuring complete combustion of gas (proper air-fuel mixture, well-maintained burners), adequate ventilation to dilute and remove combustion products, properly functioning flue systems to exhaust combustion products to the outside, and regular maintenance of gas equipment. Warning signs of incomplete combustion include yellow or orange flames, sooty deposits on equipment or cookware, excessive condensation on cold surfaces, and a stuffy or stale atmosphere in kitchen areas. Any of these signs indicates immediate investigation is required.

Carbon monoxide detectors provide an important backup safety measure. Detectors should be installed in accordance with manufacturer recommendations — typically at head height on walls, not in corners or directly above cooking equipment where they could produce false alarms from cooking fumes. Detectors should be tested regularly (monthly button test) and have batteries replaced or units replaced according to manufacturer schedules (typically 5-7 year lifespan for sealed-unit detectors). If a CO detector alarm sounds, it must be treated as a serious emergency: evacuate the area immediately, shut off gas supply if safe to do so, ventilate thoroughly, and do not re-occupy until the source of CO has been identified and corrected by qualified technicians.

subsections.heading: 5.1 Ventilation Requirements for Gas Appliances
subsections.content:
The volume of ventilation required depends on the total input rating of gas appliances, their type (open-flue appliances that draw combustion air from the room require more ventilation than room-sealed appliances), and the size of the space. Technical guidance in ITC-ICG standards specifies minimum ventilation requirements, typically expressed as square centimeters of free ventilation area per kilowatt of appliance input. In practice, commercial kitchens rely on mechanical ventilation systems with substantial capacities to meet both combustion air and cooking effluent extraction requirements.

Ventilation systems must be maintained to function effectively. This includes regular cleaning of hood filters (grease accumulation reduces airflow), professional cleaning of ductwork to remove grease deposits, verification that exhaust fans are operating at designed speeds (belts and motors maintained), and ensuring that makeup air systems are functioning to avoid excessive negative pressure. Negative pressure in kitchens can cause backdrafting — where flue gases are drawn back into the room rather than exhausting outside — creating CO hazards. Barometric dampers or makeup air systems prevent negative pressure problems.

subsections.heading: 5.2 Response to CO Detector Alarm
subsections.content:
CO detector alarms must never be ignored or disabled. If a CO detector sounds, immediate actions are: evacuate all persons from the affected area; open windows and doors to ventilate if safe to do so without delaying evacuation; shut off all gas appliances and the main gas supply; do not re-enter the area until it has been thoroughly ventilated (at least 15 minutes of ventilation with cross-breeze); call emergency services (112) if anyone is experiencing symptoms of CO poisoning; and arrange for immediate inspection by a qualified gas technician to identify the source of CO.

Common causes of CO production include blocked flues or chimneys (birds' nests, debris, structural deterioration), malfunctioning burners producing incomplete combustion, inadequate ventilation or combustion air supply, backdrafting due to negative pressure, and incorrect appliance installation. Never restart gas appliances until the cause has been identified and corrected. Persistent CO detector alarms should be documented and investigated even if no symptoms are experienced; chronic low-level CO exposure can cause health effects that develop gradually and may not be immediately attributed to CO.

sections.heading: 6. Training, Documentation, and Compliance
sections.content:
Comprehensive training is essential for gas safety. All staff who work in areas with gas installations or who operate gas equipment must receive training appropriate to their roles. Kitchen staff must understand how to safely operate gas equipment, recognize abnormal operation, detect gas leaks, follow emergency shut-off procedures, and respond to gas emergencies. Management must understand regulatory compliance requirements, maintenance schedules, inspection requirements, and their legal responsibilities for gas safety. Training should be provided during induction for new staff and refreshed at least annually, with more frequent updates if incidents occur or equipment changes.

Documentation of gas safety compliance provides both legal protection and a systematic approach to safety management. Essential documentation includes: the original installation certificate for the gas installation; periodic inspection reports and certificates; maintenance records for all gas equipment with dates, work performed, and technician details; records of staff gas safety training; gas supplier contracts and emergency contact numbers; and emergency procedures for gas leaks and CO incidents. This documentation should be organized, readily accessible, and regularly reviewed to ensure compliance items (inspections, maintenance, training) are not overdue.

Regulatory compliance extends beyond installation and maintenance to operational management. Insurance policies typically require compliance with gas safety regulations; failure to maintain periodic inspections or to address identified defects can void coverage. In the event of a gas-related incident causing injury or property damage, regulatory authorities will investigate compliance history. Evidence of systematic compliance — regular inspections, promptly addressed maintenance issues, trained staff, documented procedures — demonstrates due diligence and can significantly affect liability determinations and criminal proceedings.

subsections.heading: 6.1 Emergency Contact Information
subsections.content:
Emergency contact information for gas-related incidents must be prominently displayed in kitchen areas, management offices, and any location where staff might need to respond to gas emergencies. Essential contacts include: the gas supplier's 24-hour emergency number (for natural gas network emergencies, typically free emergency numbers); emergency services (112) for all emergencies involving injury, fire, or serious gas leaks; the establishment's authorized gas installation and maintenance company for non-emergency issues and post-incident recommissioning; and internal emergency contacts (managers, safety coordinators) who should be notified of any gas safety incidents.

Staff must understand which emergency number to call in different situations. For detected gas leaks, the gas supplier's emergency service is typically the first call (after ensuring immediate safety); they will dispatch technicians to investigate and secure the installation. For incidents involving injury, fire, or where evacuation has been necessary, emergency services (112) should be called immediately. For equipment malfunctions that are not immediate emergencies but require professional attention, the maintenance company should be contacted. Having these numbers pre-programmed in phones and posted in visible locations ensures rapid response when emergencies occur.

subsections.heading: 6.2 Continuous Improvement and Safety Culture
subsections.content:
Gas safety should be integrated into the establishment's overall safety culture. Regular safety meetings should include discussion of gas safety topics, any incidents or near-misses, and lessons learned. Staff should be encouraged and empowered to report gas safety concerns without fear of blame; many serious incidents have been preceded by warning signs that were observed but not reported. Management should respond to concerns promptly and communicate actions taken, reinforcing the importance of reporting.

Proactive safety measures include periodic walk-through inspections by managers to identify potential hazards, encouraging staff to report even minor anomalies in gas equipment operation, investigating near-miss incidents (e.g., difficult-to-light equipment, fleeting gas odors) even when no harm resulted, and continuously updating training based on experiences and industry best practices. Gas safety is not a one-time compliance exercise but an ongoing commitment requiring vigilance, training, maintenance, and a culture where every person takes responsibility for identifying and addressing hazards.

checklists.title: Daily Gas Safety Checks
items: Visually inspect all gas equipment before lighting for any visible damage or deterioration
Verify ventilation system (extraction hoods) is operating before lighting gas equipment
Check that pilot lights (where present) are lit and burning with steady blue flame
Verify gas equipment ignites quickly when opened and burns with blue flame without yellow tips
Listen for unusual sounds (hissing, whistling) that could indicate gas leaks
Check that flame failure safety devices are functioning (equipment shuts off if flame extinguishes)
Ensure combustible materials are not stored near gas equipment or lines
Verify emergency shut-off valve locations are accessible and not blocked
Check carbon monoxide detectors are functioning (green indicator light, no alarm)
Report immediately any gas odors, equipment malfunctions, or abnormal flame characteristics

checklists.title: LPG Cylinder Changeover Checklist
items: Turn off all equipment supplied by the cylinder to be changed
Close the valve on the empty cylinder completely
Allow equipment to burn off residual gas until flames extinguish
Disconnect regulator/hose from empty cylinder using appropriate tools
Move empty cylinder to designated empty cylinder storage area
Visually inspect new full cylinder for damage, corrosion, or valve problems
Check connection components (regulator, hose, washers) for wear or damage
Briefly crack open cylinder valve outdoors to clear debris from outlet
Make connection to cylinder valve ensuring proper seating and hand-tight security
Perform leak test with soapy water solution at all connection points before full opening
Only after confirming no leaks, fully open cylinder valve and resume equipment operation
Record cylinder changeover date and any issues in maintenance log

checklists.title: Gas Emergency Response Checklist
items: If gas odor detected: DO NOT operate electrical switches, phones, or spark-producing devices
Alert others verbally without using PA systems or electronic devices
Open windows and doors to ventilate (for LPG, ensure low-level ventilation)
Evacuate customers and non-essential staff to at least 50 meters distance
Shut off main gas supply valve if location is known, accessible, and safe to reach
From safe distance outside, call gas supplier emergency line and emergency services (112)
Provide clear information: location, type of gas, whether supply isolated, any injuries
Account for all staff and customers at assembly point
Do not re-enter building until gas company or emergency services declare safe
Arrange for authorized gas technician inspection before restoring gas service
Document incident including detection circumstances, actions taken, and notifications made
Review incident with staff to identify lessons learned and improve procedures

bestPractices: Establish a clear assignment of responsibility for gas safety oversight, with one designated person (manager or safety coordinator) responsible for ensuring inspections, maintenance, and training are current
Maintain a comprehensive gas safety file containing all installation certificates, inspection reports, maintenance records, and training documentation in a single, organized location
Schedule annual gas equipment maintenance during slow periods (not immediately before peak season) to allow time for any necessary repairs without operational pressure
Invest in fixed carbon monoxide detection systems rather than relying solely on portable or battery-operated detectors, particularly in basement kitchens or areas with limited natural ventilation
Conduct quarterly gas safety briefings with all kitchen staff, covering emergency procedures, shut-off valve locations, and any incidents or concerns raised

Develop relationships with reliable, responsive authorized gas installation and equipment service companies; delayed service responses can force difficult choices between safety and business continuity
Photograph gas equipment arrangements and connection configurations; these references are invaluable when verifying correct reassembly after equipment moves or maintenance
Never compromise gas safety for operational expediency; taking equipment out of service for repair may be disruptive, but operating unsafe equipment risks catastrophic consequences

glossary.Natural Gas: A fossil fuel consisting primarily of methane, delivered via pipeline networks; lighter than air, rising when leaked; has added odorant for leak detection
glossary.LPG (Liquefied Petroleum Gas): Primarily propane and butane, stored as liquid under pressure in cylinders or tanks; heavier than air, sinking when leaked and accumulating at low levels
glossary.Flame Failure Device: Safety device that automatically shuts off gas supply if flame extinguishes, preventing unburned gas accumulation; typically uses thermocouple or flame rectification sensing
glossary.Carbon Monoxide (CO): Toxic colorless, odorless gas produced by incomplete combustion; binds to blood hemoglobin preventing oxygen transport; can cause rapid unconsciousness and death
glossary.Combustion Air: Air supplied to gas appliances to support combustion; contains oxygen required for complete burning of gas; inadequate combustion air causes incomplete combustion and CO production
glossary.Odorant: Chemical compound (typically mercaptan) added to naturally odorless gas to make leaks detectable by smell; characteristic rotten egg or sulfur odor
glossary.Regulator: Device that reduces gas pressure from cylinder or supply pressure to safe operating pressure for appliances; maintains constant outlet pressure despite varying inlet pressure
glossary.Flue: Pipe or duct that conveys combustion products from gas appliances to outside atmosphere; must be properly sized, sloped, and maintained to ensure exhaust flow
glossary.Bar (pressure unit): Unit of pressure measurement; 1 bar ≈ atmospheric pressure; butane cylinders contain gas at approximately 2 bar, propane at approximately 8 bar at normal temperatures
